title: I personally hope that Ezreal will never get in with Lux, HOWEVER I do hope...
body:
... that due to a mix of the unique magic he uses plus the strong front he puts up for the world to see, he only catches the attention of the most dangerous women around. And when I'm talking about dangerous I mostly mean "beings of a higher power or in connection with said powers that remove them so far from common humanity that interaction might end lethal in a very short time". 

 An ancient celestial entity? CHECK! {{champion:142}}  A dragon? Check! {{champion:102}}  A spider? CHECK! {{champion:60}} Tentacle Priest? CHECK!  {{champion:420}} A voidling (technically)?  {{champion:145}}  Check! A darkin? (Unknown, teased in varus lore as his "sister") CHECK!

He puts out a behavior like that and asks the world to love him? Well he soon will learn the true meaning of the phrase "be careful what you wish for" with such a fanclub - and he might be able to tell Zoe to just buzz off because he wants to get with Lux, but I wonder what happens if he tries that with Elise... 

And after all that you get him actually together with Lux, only to then make him realize that she's pretty much one of the most dangerous mages of Runeterra, pretty much a humanoid weapon of mass destruction that could probably wipe an entire village of the map without breaking as much as a sweat - and probably even more dangerous than all of the above combined.

Look man usually I don't really care about this whole shipping thing, but an arrogant brat like Ezreal deserves a little more... danger in his life, I think we can all agree on that. 

{{sticker:slayer-jinx-wink}} 

(Also YES I GET IT THIS IS HERESY FOR THE HOLY TARIC SHIP, but please just consider this for a minute)

It'd definitely be comical with all the different scenarios and interactions he ends up having.

I'm for it.

It works just so well because you know Ezreal will by default play the "cool guy" (tm), but he will also be scared as hell as he's not stupid and kind of knows what he's dealing with. However, the prideful "cool guy act" will forbid him from actually backing out, while his very understanable fear makes a proper rejection impossible. 

This combination means that he will never get out of this mess by himself, and he's just digging the hole he's in deeper and deeper, all because he's such a proud, so smart yet so stupid brat. The story almost writes itself at that point, he's just the ideal character for this setup.

While pre-update Ezreal might have been endearing, I imagine this new one would just turn Lux off with his arrogance and emptiness, especially once she’d read about what he’d done with that artifact.  Yikes.

Also, an arrogant and insecure guy who won’t take no for an answer sounds like the start of a rather cringey or even creepy story, rather than the romantic comedy you have in mind.  What’s he gonna do once she politely but firmly turns him down?

I think this is a very biased and negative interpretation of the character, but it's one that EASILY could become true if Ezreal does not mature. Should he not evolve off his current path, he will learn all the wrong lessons instead of the right ones and become a villain. 

That said, you SHOULD worry about Ez. It's what we do for characters we love. Care and worry makes for good stories. It's not as dire as you paint it, but it could get there. He's on what's called an "evolution plot". If he doesn't change his ways, he moves to the opposite path, a "devolution plot". To see what this looks like, watch Better Call Saul. 

BTW: you can root for a character and not like them. This is how lots of fiction works.

Yay, you replied again!  It’s so cool to talk to the people writing this.

I object to the word “mature,” since it implies that children are naturally like Ezreal and must just grow out of it.  Children, like adults, generally understand right and wrong.  But some of them just don’t care.  They only get worse as they get older, so we must notice them early and not delude ourselves about what they really are, or squeamish about what we must do.  Isolate, confine, and _forget_.

Ezreal is one of them.  Even if he had his parents, he would not have been much different.  He belongs in jail, with his estate confiscated by the state.  And speaking of Better Call Saul, Saul is just a degenerate who disgraces the ethical oaths he swore for a quick buck.  When the judge finds out about his misdeeds, we can only hope he adds a lengthy felony stay in state prison to the removal of Saul’s license.

Ah, you are arguing nature vs nurture. I'd recommend watching Better Call Saul, and Breaking Bad for excellent meditations on power, nature, and maturity. And yes, Saul is a degenerate -- but we LOVE Jimmy and want him to be right and stay on the straight and narrow, despite knowing how the story ends.  Empathy is fascinating.

Maturity is a general term that implies biology, emotional, and psychological elements. In Ez's case -- he's immature. He is like a child. Not all children are like Ez -- that's your projection/definition -- and in no way does that mean all kids are like Ez. 

Isolate, confine, and forget is how we get monsters lurking in the closet. 

Ezreal is not a monster. Again, he has one inside and he could potentially become one, but to me there's a heart in Ez that yearns to come out into the light. Then again, as a tireless optimist, I believe in the best in all people. Decision, consequence, and change whittle us into new people one stroke at a time. Do not be so hasty to dismiss and condemn. The fact that we are having this conversation means that new Ez is working. Given my druthers, I would write him until Riot ultimately leads me out behind the dev shed and puts me down, of all the champs I've worked on, he's one of the few that I feel has SOOOOOOO much more story potential.

At some point I remember that I'm not here on the boards to convince anyone to like Ez. That's honestly a Herculean effort and going against what I believe about characters. Once we judge a character, we cement who they are in our minds, and only further stories can convince us otherwise. I don't want to interfere directly with someone else's perception of the character/work. All I will say is each choice, each line, and each story beat was intentionally placed. Some people, for reasons I can't understand, solve bits of the puzzle and then get mad at the puzzle. 

There's an old saying about storytelling: "the villain at noon is the hero by three". If people don't like where we placed Ez in League, that's okay. Strong reactions indicate passion. My only hope is I get to share with you all the long term and short term arcs I planned for Ezreal while writing him, because there is a LOT more to say with him. 

If you can't see or find the heart of the character hiding under his obvious overcompensation, that's okay! I'm not going to point it out to anyone. You can not like things and disagree with an author's choices. I accept this. If someone wants to believe Ezreal is a sociopathic affluenza monster, well I'm really not one to invalidate anyone's opinion. My guess is that characters who don't earn or suffer for their rewards infuriate others who have to suffer and work hard. This is VERY true in life. People have very odd reactions to those who lead "charmed lives" like Ezreal. Not to be confused with Semi-Charmed Life by Third Eye Blind, one of the most underrated rock acts of the late 1900's/early 2000's (and still going strong today!). Those to whom it seems everything comes naturally or easily are prone to being immediately hated or discounted. 

And yes, Ezreal is very distrustful of more bilgewater residences. He does love a good game of Krakenhand, even though he doesn't know how to play. Lucky bastard.
In fairness he didn't have much nice to say about noxus demacia or piltover either lol

Hi, just thought I would chime in if that's okay!

But personally I'm fine with how new Ezreal has been set. I get that childish demeanor and nothing else can be a contrast to the old Ezreal we know, and that some people think he's a bad person now because of it, but I find him to be believable, given his backstory. His attempts to act cool and cocky to gain recognition feels organic, considering he's missed the love and attention from his parents for a good majority of his life, he needs to find approval from others to compensate.

This makes him, I would say...desperate? But to me, that's what makes it realistic. I believe despite his smug outward appearance, deep down there is a good soul in Ez, a guy that wants to explore the world, but also work to make it a better place.

That's just my take on it though!

(I assume you know Magic the Gathering color philosophy?)

And this kind of argument that Ifneth makes is why Green is a bloody toxic color and why Blue is so much better. There is an inherent pessimism in Green's belief in an hypothetical "true nature", and you can justify the worst atrocities with it.

Sure, Blue isn't perfect, and you can definitely push it too far and get some pretty awful results too, but at least Blue *tries*, and a balanced Blue view that doesn't go too far is healthy. Whereas even a balanced Green view is... harmless but useless? Accept your fate? What good does it do?

Gaah, the older I get, the less I understand how people can like Green and consciously defend Green philosophy...

_____

Anyhoo, rant over, let's come back to Ezreal. I'm always glad when a writer is enthusiast about a character, it's usually a good sign that the character is in good hands and will be treated well and that we will get good stories out of it. So yay, props to you, have fun with Ezreal. \o/

That being said, I see plenty of other characters with just as much potential AND themes that are more interesting to me on a personal level. Xayah's rebellion, Taliyah's struggles to re-build her life, Illaoi's meddling in Bilgewater, all of them (and more) deal with topics closer to my heart, and I hope someone will give them as much love as you'll give to Ezreal :)

On paper, logistically I would say Ezreals' chances are very good based on his background. He's an explorer that goes to exciting new places and Lux comes from a very insular oppressive society that would look down on her for what she is. The real world parallel that immediately comes to my mind is slut shaming in conservative third world countries, girls coming to America as exchange students from countries that have very narrow views on extra-marital sex are usually slamdunks because a natural urge has been suppressed and can now be explored in a vacuum of complete non-judgement.

tl;dr Ezreal can 100% pull Lux if he gets his foot out of his mouth and stops self-sabotaging, but he won't because... character development?

First, don’t talk about “women” like they’re all the same.  They’re people, and each one is different.

Second, Ezreal’s ego problems and shallow motivations are obvious, undermining his efforts to charm anyone, much less a young lady who’s spent much of her life learning courtly politics.  She would see right through him.

And what’s behind him isn’t pretty.  He’s just as obsessed with his image on the inside as he is on the outside, and he’s just as reckless in private as in public.  There’s no reason for Lux to want to a second date, if he could even convince her to go on the first.

Third, Lux doesn’t seem repressed in general, and it’s a stereotype that kids who aren’t ‘allowed’ to do things at home will necessarily go wild in college.  Some just don’t want to.  Lux, in particular, just wants not to be hated and feared for her powers.  I doubt Ezreal is sensitive enough to help her with those feelings.  And that’s just the problem: there’s nothing to like about him that isn’t superficial.

So when the time for the redemption arc comes, Ezreal just won’t redeem himself.  He has no reason to.  Why not just chase some other girl—one with fewer diplomatic strings and who won’t be leaving soon?  By your logic, Piltover should have plenty of others.

Just sharing what I've seen in my own personal experience of life, friend. Of course men and women are are different in many esoteric indeterminable ways, I never suggested they weren't or that there is a "one size fits all approach" to women, BUT there are undeniable patterns that you start to recognize that are separate from simple personality differences. Constants that are more associated with age, upbringing, social norms and cultural differences. Constants in any seduction that are simply effective because they prime someones biology bypassing everything else because it appeals to them on a more primal level. It's like they say, Attraction isn't a Choice (google it, it's a good read). That's more what I'm getting at. Of course these surface level differences are still important which is why you should always try to determine the girls "blueprint" beforehand.
 
Second you seem to be confusing my point. That attraction is NOT based on a moral standing or strong ethical boundaries, quite frankly I wish that was true would make dating in general simpler. Just be a good dude and get all the girls lol. Unfortunately that's a very one-dimensional way of looking at it and overly idealistic to boot in my opinion. Without an overarching strategy and a good "hook" you're just going to be playing the numbers game and probably not going to be attracting many quality girls. A "hook" in this scenario could be the unrepentant bad boy that the girl wants to "fix" him. I actually don't like this hook in real life as it can be disingenuous but you would have to be crazy to admit it isn't compelling. Just one look at the media targeted at women confirms this (50 shades, romcoms etc etc).

Third. While you are right the "small town girl in the big city" stereotype is very much a stereotype, but like all stereotypes there is some truth to it or it wouldn't exist at all. In my own personal experience being a former college student and working for a big company that employed a lot  exchange students, it's one that was proved true with almost freakish regularity. You may be different, associate with different kinds of people or have a different experience of life and that's fine, but this is what I have experienced and I'm sure many others who are open-minded can corroborate that they have seen a similar side to people.

And finally
>  By your logic, Piltover should have plenty of others.

Not at all. I was merely applying a "blueprint" to Lux that I have found effective when comparing to other girls that are in a similar situation to her. If Piltover already is the free "America" in this context doing that would be COUNTER to what I suggested. You are right in a way though. Abundance is always good so Ez should also learn how to attract women in Piltover/ in general and not just rely on gimmicks that can make you very much a one-trick pony so to speak.

Again League of Legends lore is a work of fiction and is thus subject to the injection of ideals, values and group-think mentalities above raw attraction so that it is easy to digest for all. A conventional pickup cannot work because it doesn't convey a message that can be mass marketed. Ezreal will get the girl because he changed for her and we should all strive to be better OR he won't get the girl because Lux is a strong independent Demacian who don't need no man. Unless this story was being marketed as a romance story and had some nuance in it. In the mainstream true love conquerors all is much more... palatable I guess is the word I'd use.

Or you could just say “Hi,” ask them about what they do and what their interests are, and see if you have anything in common.  If so, then enjoy the conversation and ask for their contacts once one of you must leave.  If not, then on to the next one.  Even if they turn out to be taken, you’ll still have had a nice conversation and made a good acquaintance or friend.

While this does work on strangers, you have better odds of meeting someone you like at places where you can meet people you like, such as book clubs, churches, non-profits, etc.  Look around, and if anyone there interests you, just say “Hi!”.  There’s no trick—just the effort and patience it takes to make anything that lasts.

There is no trick.  They know what you want, and if you’re polite, considerate, and genuinely interested in them as people, they’re generally _happy_ about it.  You would be, too.  Just take it easy and don’t make it awkward if it turns out she’s not the girl of your dreams. :D

Lol ok. I do have to ask if you are yourself a woman at this point. That's just some very watered down mainstream advice no offense. What you're saying is actually 100% true in a sense, but it betrays a more complete picture that the woman isn't really required to think about from her side of the interaction.

It's kind of like saying true love conquerors all or Be Yourself! Or Freedom, Justice and the American Way! Or saying money won't make you happy. All true in their own way but NOT completely true. Saccharine sweet ideals that aren't nuanced enough to explore a deeper side.

It's hard to explain what I'm saying because technically every point you made is correct. Make interesting conversation, play the field, be patient but there is another side to it that you are completely ignoring. If you are a woman I would actually understand because typically (and I hesitate to make a gross generalizations that might make you mad at me again =P) the guy approaches the girl and if you're a girl you're just not going to see where I'm coming from.

To the contrary, saying “Hi!” and starting a conversation where you two get to know each other gives you both a chance to decide whether you like each other, have shared interests, and want the same things from life.  You need to have it, and sooner rather than later, so just talk to her.  It’s not that hard.

She does know that guys often judge a girl who initiates, yet she still wants someone as much as they do.  So, she either just says the heck with that, and believes everyone should be able to talk to everyone else, or is kinda traditional and does hope a boy comes by.  As long as you’re polite and sincere, it won’t kill you, her, or the chance for a healthy relationship.  In fact, it’s the foundation for one.

And speaking of foundations, you won’t have any chance of building anything with someone who just doesn’t work for you.  The best chance to meet them is at gatherings, like interest clubs, house parties, or events.  And if you think that all this talk is for girls, then you’ve been missing out. :/

Edit: Example scene of Ezreal and Lux to prove my point.

>Utensils clacked and scraped against plates as ice clinked in glasses and dozens of voices murmured and chattered in the warmly lit hall where Ezreal had chosen to celebrate his mapping of the Piltovian catacombs.

>Standing only to the waists of the very important ladies and gentlemen all around him, he was shocked to see someone his size.  She had a bob of blond hair and two cute blue eyes, just like his, and as he caught himself staring at her, they gave a look that made something in him melt.

>It was the same look mom gave dad when he’d been messing around with hextech gadgetry in the basement, while they had been around.  It was warm and stern and curious—and she was smiling just like him.  With a blush, he walked over and said, “H-hi!”
